docs.lead_paragraph: PARIS -- The last time anyone played a Grand Slam tennis match, Novak Djokovic required nearly six hours to finish off Rafael Nadal in the Australian Open final. Just what extremes might be required of the leading men on the gritty, rally-extending red clay at the French Open, which begins Sunday?

headline.main: In New World Of Tennis, It's Survival Of the Fittest

docs.snippet: PARIS -- The last time anyone played a Grand Slam tennis match, Novak Djokovic required nearly six hours to finish off Rafael Nadal in the Australian Open final.     Just what extremes might be required of the leading men on the gritty,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Mary Lou Retton, the first American female gymnast to win a gold medal in the all-around, was the star of the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles. She won five medals, including two silvers, for team and vault, and two bronzes, for uneven bars and floor exercise. More recently, Sue Sylvester, Jane Lynch's fictional character on the Fox show ''Glee,'' made a passing reference to Retton as her worst enemy. And Retton is among the former athletes whose retro images are being featured on Wheaties boxes.

headline.main: 30 Seconds With Mary Lou Retton: Gleefully Devoted To Motherhood

docs.abstract: Excerpts from 30 Seconds Q&A with Mary Lou Retton, the Olympic all-around champion in 1984; she is raising four daughters and three of them are gymnasts. Photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With the physical demands rising at the Grand Slam events, the top players are relying on full-time personal trainers and more to help them stay fit.

headline.seo: Men’s Tennis Has Become Survival of the Fittest
headline.print_headline: In New World Of Tennis, It’s Survival Of the Fittest

docs.abstract: Elite tennis players are relying on full-time personal trainers and more to stay fit as the physical demands rise at Grand Slam events; the stars, who earn tens of millions of dollars a year, can build a professional support team that the rank and file cannot match.
docs.snippet: With the physical demands rising at the Grand Slam events, the top players are relying on full-time personal trainers and more to help them stay fit.

docs.lead_paragraph: Parents are questioning the long-term effects of the often-used laxative, Miralax, which has become a staple in many American households since it was first introduced 13 years ago.

headline.seo: Miralax, a Drug for Adults, Is Popular as a Children’s Remedy
headline.main: Drug for Adults Is Popular as Children’s Remedy
headline.print_headline: Drug for Adults Is Popular as Children’s Remedy

docs.abstract: Many doctors prescribe the laxative Miralax as a long-term solution for childhood constipation, despite the fact that the Food and Drug Administration has only approved it for short-term use in adults; drug has no known severe side effects, but a number of parents and doctors are concerned about the lack of studies on its effects in children.
docs.snippet: Parents are questioning the long-term effects of the often-used laxative, Miralax, which has become a staple in many American households since it was first introduced 13 years ago.

docs.lead_paragraph: Concern over the possible health and environmental effects of such food has prompted a move for labeling it, but scientists, farmers and technology companies call the measures alarmist.

headline.seo: Dispute Over Labeling of Genetically Modified Food
headline.main: Battle Brewing Over Labeling of Genetically Modified Food
headline.print_headline: Battle Brewing Over Labeling Of Genetically Modified Food

docs.abstract: Concerns about the health and environmental effects of biotechnology are fueling a movement to require that food from genetically modified crops be labeled, if not eliminated; labeling bills have been proposed in more than a dozen states over the last year; most closely watched effort is a proposed ballot initiative in California that has cleared a crucial hurdle, setting the stage for a probable November vote that could influence not just food packaging but the future of American agriculture.
docs.snippet: Concern over the possible health and environmental effects of such food has prompted a move for labeling it, but scientists, farmers and technology companies call the measures alarmist.
